page.title: 14THE ARUN GAP BEYOND S. STOKE
page.content: North of South Stoke farming is influenced by the new course of the river Arun and its old meander across the valley. The resulting wet-lands caused by the new and the old river beds provide good grazing for cattle. This pasture is rented out for sheep to crop in winter, from elsewhere. The meander forms a wide circular swamp, dense with willow and undergrowth. Within its circle is grassland and deciduous trees and copses are numerous. the land rises abruptly from this basin to a higher level along which runs a farmers track from North Stoke to the downs. Here arable replaces pasture. Looking back down the valley all seems in miniature. South Stoke, the railway, the river, the cattle - remote and peaceful, but motorists heading for the Downs dispel any quiet stillness.
